Posts.Content: justsylvie wrote: Hi ladies  I've been lurking and reading like a madwoman for the last month or so... ever since I found out that my initial 2006 breast cancer has come back... with a nasty vengeance. Mets to lungs, bones, and liver. Icck. So, I just want to say hi at the moment, and thank you all for so much amazing information which has been helping me process what's happening. You've already given me so much hope, because reading your stories and finding out that so many of you have been living (really living, not just existing) with Stage 4 for many years has been exactly what I needed to hear. When I first found out the cancer spread, I may have panicked a teensy bit. LOL The stats are terrifying out there. But reading all your stories and realities of living with it has shown me it isn't as dire as it initially seemed. New meds are coming out all the time, and it appears the old prognosis stats are no longer valid. So, again, thank you. You have already helped so much and I appreciate you! I'll post more as I can (trying to get some major rest after months of coughing from the lung mets).  And in the meantime, I'm saying hi to a wonderful group of ladies who are all part of an unfortunate close knit community. Hi. :) Dx 8/10/2006, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IIIA, 5/17 nodes, ER+, HER2+ Surgery 9/11/2006 Lymph node removal: Left; Mastectomy: Left; Prophylactic ovary removal Chemotherapy 10/11/2006 Gemzar (gemcitabine), Taxol (paclitaxel) Radiation Therapy 2/5/2007 Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 3/1/2007 Femara (letrozole) Dx 12/20/2012, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER+, HER2+ Chemotherapy 1/11/2013 Taxol (paclitaxel) Chemotherapy 1/1/2014 Navelbine (vinorelbine) Chemotherapy 9/25/2014 Xeloda (capecitabine) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Saying hi... reluctantly justsylvie Annie62

Posts.Title: Saying hi... reluctantly justsylvie Annie62

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2013 11:01AM justsylvie wrote: Thanks so much for the big warm welcome, ladies. As much as none of us want to be in this club, the fact that we aren't alone helps enormously. Having a place to vent, rant, weep, and not always have to be so damn strong for everyone, is exactly what I need, I think. When breast cancer first hit, I set up a blog ( www.breastcancervictory.com ) to tell my story and keep me on track for personal healing. This was huge for me, because I tend to be a very private person on emotional stuff.  Doing the blog publicly helped keep me focused on the positive as much as possible. Once I hit the "five year all clear" mark, I was fine with never posting to the blog again, thinking I was all done with it and could move on with my life. Now, I am trying to get up my nerve and energy to post the "crap, it's back" blog post I'm dreading.  But in the meantime, getting through the initial rush of doctor's appointments, scans, chemo, etc etc etc is taking up most of my energy. Starting to feel a bit better with my first two chemo treatments. This gives me major hope. If we can get the lung issue under control, my prognosis dramatically increases. (Lymphangitic Carcinomatosis is the official term for how the breast cancer metasticized into my lungs)  I went through months of hell because my "regular" doctor kept throwing antibiotics at me for "double pneumonia" instead of bothering to check for cancer, so my body has been rather weakened for a while now. I lost a lot of weight way too fast. Now that I am getting treatments, it is getting easier to breathe, and my appetite is improving. I'm feeling stronger every day, and that makes me very happy. So, I'm starting to accept that I am part of this club for the rest of my life. Once I can take that, I can start looking at  longer term plans. I have always been a planner, and right now, I hate not being able to plan my future at all. That's hard for me.  OK, now I'm officially rambling, so I'll stop here for now. :) Thanks again for the hugs and welcomes.
Posts.Title: Saying hi... reluctantly justsylvie Annie62
